result.execSummary:
The defendant Scott A McCartney was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of Drug Paraphernalia - County Ordinance. This is not a criminal offense and results only in a money penalty for this offense.
  • Possession of Marijuana - County Ordinance. This is not a criminal offense and results only in a money penalty for this offense.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Fine to be paid in 20 days or penalty of Civil Judgment for non-payment.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Scott A McCartney

records.addlTxt:
09:44 AM Defendant Scott A McCartney in court.  Christian Farina appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

Defense acknowledges receipt of complaint and waives reading of complaint.  
Service admitted/advised of charges and potential penalties.  

COUNT 1:

Prosecuting attorney moves to amend charge to Possession of Drug Paraphernalia contrary to ordinance 13-102(C)(14), Waukesha County Ordinances. 
Court approves amendment. 
No contest plea entered.  
The Court Orders the Following:	
$360.80 within 20 days. Failure to pay;  the Court orders civil judgment entered.

COUNT 2:

Prosecuting attorney moves to amend charge to Possession of Marijuana contrary to ordinance 13-102(C)(13), Waukesha County Ordinances. 
Court approves amendment. 
No contest plea entered.  
The Court Orders the Following:	
THE COURT WAIVES FINE AND WILL ONLY APPLY COSTS.
$205.80 within 20 days. Failure to pay;  the Court orders civil judgment entered.
State's Demand for Discovery and Inspection and Notice of Intent to Use Defendant's Statement and DNA Evidence.
